title: Will the monthly U.S. civilian unemployment rate (U3) reach or exceed 4.0% for any month before 1 November 2020?
preds: Given the Thursday announcements (https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/jobless-claims) its hard to see how we will not reach 4%, relatively soon.  I'm revising to a certainty based on these results.

The economic repercussions from the coronavirus crisis are piling up around the globe. Data Tuesday showed a U.S. gauge of activity at service providers and manufacturing contracted the most on record. A similar measure in the U.K. dropped to the lowest since the series began in 1998.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-24/dollar-sheds-status-as-king-after-fed-ushers-in-return-of-risk The U.S. experienced an unprecedented 45% year-on-year slump in imports from China during the first two weeks of March, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence. The consumer electronics industry is taking a hard hit with a 66% drop in Chinese shipments of machinery and electronics and a 64% decline in imports of computers compared with a year earlier. https://finance.yahoo.com/news/world-trade-rocked-virus-sees-080000277.html
As of February 2020 the unemployment rate was at 3.5%. With the increase of claims at 3.5milion and rising we will exceed 4% before November 1, 2020.

Cutting forecast in half. Feb rate was 3.5 percent with decent job growth. Lock downs, cancellations, reduced travel, work from home may translate to some days of missed work and even a recession later. But employment is always lagging reality and this question ends in October.

3.5% as of today's labour market data. There are two aspects to this question: 1) coronavirus-related layoff risk and 2) labour force participation rate - even if hiring stays strong, then unemployment can rise if the number of more discouraged/disabled workers who come back into the labour force looking for work is higher than the number of jobs being added. NB that when you include these workers (the discouraged, part-timers looking for more), the real unemployment figure is more like 7% and probably higher if you include some number of disabled people who could find work in a sufficiently tight labour market.

We are nearly two months into this 10 month question. To simulate a random walk I put on a surgical mask, closed my eyes and walked thru my house while listening to the stock market. I used the red/green of the 3 major market indexes to tell me when to stop and when to go. I turned at each stop a quarter turn to the left. I then counted the number of times I bumped into a wall and divided that by the number of times I stopped. My result is the same as this is an election year and employment is still a lagging indicator. Even with a potential 20% market correction we are unlikely to see unemployment increase significantly in 8 months.

The unemployment rate jumped to 3.6 percent because more people are entering the labor force.  Thus, the number of people counted in the labor force is growing.   Yet, the rate of GDP growth is slowing.  The growing labor force means there are a lot more marginal employees in jobs that quickly disappear when the economy turns south  (e.g., temporary production workers, delivery drivers and stockroom employees to handle increased orders)  who could be quickly laid off in a recession.  I am not sure what the effect of the coronavirus will be.  There are some news articles that suggest the effect will be great.  However, the bird flu virus did not effect the economy very much, except of course for poultry farmers.  Yet, I reduced my estimate because oil prices fell in the last two weeks.

Reran forecast using triple exponential smoothing and a random walk forecast.  I then averaged the results.  There is still a downward trend that if it continues, makes a surge over 4% unlikely.  Therefore, I'm revising my forecast downward to 10%.
Forward curves peg the rate at 3.6% at EOY. Economy fundamentals are strong though markets are jittery.

The latest data from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York-model (\url{https://www.newyorkfed.org/research/capital_markets/ycfaq.html#/}) is dated ''December 2019" and has a 12-month probability of 23.62% based on the Yield Curve. The 12 months will cover Jan 2020 to Dec 2020. Bloomberg has a ''Recession"-tracker (https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/us-economic-recession-tracker/) that seems to take more variables into account. Their latest forecast is from Jan 15th 2020 and gives a 26% chance of a recession in the next 12 months (I presume this means from Feb 2020 to Jan 2021). How should we interpret these probabilities? I assume that if a recession starts in month X it will last for some time. Let's say for the rest of the period that we are looking at. So a recession that starts in Apr 2020 will last (at least) until Dec 2020 (for the Federal Reserve data) or Jan 2021 (for the Bloomberg data). When the probability for a recession is x% in the next 12 months, then the probability for NO recession in this period is (100-x)%. The probability per month that there is no recession is then (1-x)^(1/12). (This implies independence and that is probably not the case). The probability per month that there is no recession, based on the forecast by the Federal Reserve Bank, is then 0.9778%. When we use the Bloomberg prognosis it is 0.9752%. From historic data we know that in a recession the unemployment rate rises at about 0.23% per month. The latest data (December 2020) has unemployment at 3.5% and it is steady around this value now for about 4 months. So it would take about 2 months to reach the limit of 4%. This means that the recession would have to start at the latest on 2010-09-01 or before that.  Working with the data of the Federal Bureau Bank there are 8 months to go. The probability that there is \textbf{no} recession is 0.9778^8=0.8356. 
Working with the Bloomberg data there are 7 months to go. The probability that there is NO recession is 0.9752^}=0.8388.  Conclusion: about 84% chance that there is no recession (or 16% that there is a recession) in the period of interest. Because there is already a chance of 14% that the 4%-limit can be broken without a recession I put the overall probability at 20%. The figure to look out for is the unemployment rate: does it keep steady at around 3.5% or not?

This is an interesting one.   Time series data for the past 10 years shows a dramatic fall in the unemployment rate.  Currently the unemployment rate is quite low.  The past decade has been a time of unusually low interest rates.   Folks seem confident that the FED won't reverse course and tighten before November so it's possible the economy may remain stable during this period, consumer spending may continue apace, and the unemployment rate may stay low.   If you take the data for the past 10 years and search for the time (in months) for the rate either to increase by 0.5% or decrease by 0.5% there is some nice fluctuation to be seen.   55% of the time, this happens in 5 months or less.  23% of the time this happens between 5 and 10 months.  23% of the time this happens between 10 and 16 months.   There has never been a period longer than 16 months during this time when the unemployment rate did not either rise or fall by 0.5.   There are almost 10 months to go on this question.  If we look backward we have already been in the 4% - 3% band for 11 months.  So if the answer is to be 0% the rate will have to stay within this band for 20 months altogether.  Perhaps this should make me nervous. Also, when you get closer to zero unemployment, the unemployed population becomes more and more difficult to employ for various reasons.  At some point, as economic circumstances change, you approach a barrier that makes the rate more likely to rise than to fall, so when it does change, perhaps it will be more likely to go to 4% rather than 3%. An 0.5% fluctuation isn't much, so it could happen.  An additional straw in the wind is the news that some Boeing suppliers have run out their string on the 737 Max debacle and have announced layoffs just recently.    When the question ends, either the unemployment rate will have exceeded 4% or it will not have done so.   Despite all the aforementioned negative factors, I have to say I don't think this will happen.   Maybe I will be wrong, but I think it's a decent bet.
I have continually underestimated the ability of US to generate jobs. It will come to a debt-fuelled end but not sure it will happen before November. Dropping to 25.

This is a very interesting question, I like how there are vastly differing opinions and ways to think about base rates to be found. Some previous comments that influenced my thinking so far: @jtrommel mentioning a 14% probability from analysis of the time course, but forecasting quite a lot higher based on the probability of a recession: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/936623 @cafebedouin getting 46% and 61% base rates looking at historic data:  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/936124 My take so far: Since 1948, there have been 71 November to October time frames (the time frame the question is referring to). In 67 of these Nov-Oct time frames, there was at least one month with a reported U3 rate of 4.0% or above, giving a base rate of 94.4%. Interestingly, in the last 20 years, all Nov-Oct timeframes had at least one U3 rate a 4% or above. Putting it yet a different way, it would be the first time since Nov 1968 to Oct 1969 that the U3 would be below 4.0% for all months of this period. What are arguments in favor of U3<4% for any month in the time frame?
- the presidential election year was mentioned multiple times in the discussion, and I agree that this might lead to higher than usual efforts to keep the data looking favorable
- @Chrisp mentions some indicators that encourage a stable/positive outlook with respect to unemployment:  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/936720 , https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/936743
- the current expansion has been going a lot longer than many have predicted or expected - maybe it will keep going just that little bit longer (with a little help from a president running for re-election)? I am starting to think that there might also be some fundamental economic mechanisms that are shifting, rendering some of the approaches to thinking about the economy that used to work less useful.  What are arguments against U3<4% for any month in the time frame?
- the above base rate is very high for at least one month hitting or exceeding 4% 
- with unemployment rates below 4%, this is close to (or maybe by definition already) full-employment - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_employment . Even in a strong economy that would continue to support full employment in that sense, the unemployment rate is at its practical minimum. The probability that the rate would hit or exceed 4% as part of the "noise" I judge to be very high.
A lot of indicators say people returning to the work force could drive this up.

The time series itself is not complicated. Different models (ETS, ARIMA) give almost the same probability that the 4% limit will be broken (14%). However, history tells us that the unemployment curve is severely disrupted when there is a recession. From former recessions we learn that on average the unemployment rate rises with 0.23% per month. At the moment (data Nov 2019) we are at 3.5%. It would take little more than 2 months before the limit of 4% is broken. So the real question is: will there be a recession in the first nine months of 2020? The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has a model. The success rate of this model in the period from 1961 up to now is 5/9=56%: in the nine situations where the model had a peak probability for a recession of 40% or less (about what is predicted for Aug 2020), the recession did materialise in 5 cases. However: the Fed did react swiftly when the spread (this is the predictor that the Fed's model uses) went negative in the period from Jun 2019 to Sep 2019. So this might have an impact. Therefore I take my forecast a bit lower than 56% and put it on 40%.
Adjusting down based on consensus street opinion that I’m reading. Break in the job market seems unlikely

I’ve been doing a lot of thinking on this topic. I think I was being a little too high level with my initial forecast. I failed to properly account for the serial correlation inherent in data like unemployment and inflation. To take a step back, I started thinking about what it would take to get 4% U3.  With the labor force at 160m, the US would need to lose 800k jobs for unemployment to hit 4%. That is an average of 67k jobs per month over the next 12 months. To further contextualize it, the US lost 8m jobs in the financial crisis (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/PAYEMS) While I think there are risks to the US outlook, an employment loss of that magnitude seems unlikely without a significant demand shock. Further, the willingness of the Fed to provide accommodation should prevent smaller risks from materializing.  Therefore, I’m thinking the appropriate base rate was closer to 35%. Continued strength in the labor marker, lower investment in productivity enhancement, removal of near-term risks (https://seekingalpha.com/article/4312425) all pull the odds closer to 20%. I think present times reflect a similar dynamic as 2015-2016 where unemployment declined despite a static participation. All-in, 18%
The current trend will fade since it is not due to the policies of the present admin. but those of the last.

(Thanks to nigster for the links.) I did some more research on the yield curve inversion as an indicator of an upcoming recession [1][2]. And the average lag time between inversion and recession is 20 months, which would put it in 2021, outside the time frame of this question.  [1] https://www.forbes.com/sites/greatspeculations/2019/10/02/inverted-yield-curve-suggesting-recession-around-the-corner/#5ec2840f2345
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/08/business/yield-curve-recession-indicator.html
@Dillyweed makes some great points. Expecting gnarly (volatile) US markets and macro May-Jul'20.

Unemployment will start to go up by the summer of 2020. Recessions tend to start between 6-24 months after the rate of the 3 month treasury bonds rises above the 10 year treasury bond. Also recessions are about 6-12 months away after that inversion reinverts so that the 3 month is back to normal, being below the 10 year rate. The rate inverted in May 2019, they deinverted in October 2019 about a month after the new york fed had started pumping about $160 billion per day into the repo market. The fed rate is only 1 indicator for recession, the quantitative easing by the fed is another indicator. It looks like summer is when the economy should see some job losses. I predict that the job losses will balloon over time to affect the financial market, when the financial market begins to fall apart this will cause the funds (which wall st depends on) to also fall apart which will create a feedback loop between it and the bigger economy (the "consumer").  The last recession was pushed back from a depression by looting the retirement funds, but this time around I dont see what there is for the elite to loot since the average westerner lives paycheck to paycheck. So we will see if this time around turns into a depression. Either way, the job losses might be delayed from the summer, but I see no way that the government or the business sector could possibly push the job losses back past the winter. I think the unemployment rate should reach 4% very quickly once the job losses begin. We should see investment bank bankruptcies soon (a few months) following it. The infection will spread to the entire western world in a week or two. China will be fine though, as long as they continue their trade war with the west and refuse to give in. The trade war has had the positive effect of insulating their economy from the west. Iran is in a similar position.

Will the monthly U.S. civilian unemployment rate (U3) reach or exceed 4.0% for any month before 1 November 2020? 
Our recessions seems to be in hiding at the moment and economic inertia is a mighty force. While the rate may tick up as job growth slows, the rate may be moderate for the next 10 months.
In historical terms 4% unemployment is pretty low. Given that the economy is showing signs of slowing, I'm guessing there is a high probability of rising at least this high in the next 11 months.

higher odds of a recession but unemployment rate is typically a lagging indicator so haircutting to account for lag

a move to 4% would be a significant reversal. Slow global and national economic data suggests this is plausible, but far from likely. Yet probability distribution from a global economic shock is skewed to the downside, pushing my estimate higher.

It's been below 4% since January of this year and is on a downward trend, from which I project an annual average of about 3.6% for 2020. Fluctuations over recent years have been about 0.5% (+/- .25% from the annual average), suggesting that it's quite unlikely to see a month above 4% (3.85% would be the expected high value), but not impossible. I may update this in coming months with the benefit of more data.
Feels unlikely without a recession and that doesn't look particularly likely in the next year.
Much can slip twixt cup and lip. Very early days, but this is a start.

..Will rely upon the following info. (links below) for an initial forecast. Question is whether unemployment will reach/exceed 4.0% in any month, requiring a higher probability than I might use under different requirements. U.S. unemployment rate last reached 4.0 in January, 2019 (..and in June 2018 before that). Since the end of 2016 this rate has tended to be at its highest in January + February of the year. Latest rate, from October 2019 is 3.6%: https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000.  4-week moving average of initial jobless claims appears slightly higher for November so far, but other, temporary factors may be involved: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/IC4WSA, https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/14/weekly-jobless-claims-november-14.html (Some outlooks for 2020...:) https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/UNRATEMD https://www.kiplinger.com/article/business/T019-C000-S010-unemployment-rate-forecast.html https://www.thebalance.com/us-economic-outlook-3305669

The current economy continues to create jobs and even a slowing will take time to begin to affect this statistic.  More time than projected in this question.  After the next election it is possible depending on who ends of winning.

I’m going to use the union probability for multiple events to calculate this question out.  Employment is a lagging indicator to economic strength. In the US it should follow consumer/business confidence. Over the next 2 months, I think the probability is low (2%), in Q2, 2020 I expect the probability to double (4%), in June and July (6% and 8%), August (8%), and Sept and Oct (10-%).  Obviously, the probabilities are very subjective. A 2% increase or decrease in each probably shows a range of 31% to 65%. I want to see  the economic outlooks to come out from the banks/asset managers, but the Survey of Professional forecasters is suggesting a 38% chance of annual average unemployment exceeding 4%. This makes me more confident in my 57% probability for any one month spike

This a 'do you think economic growth will weaken' question in disguise, where one has to remember that the unemployment rate is a lagging indicator of economic activity. The previous inversion of the yield curve suggests that a recession will happen. The fact that yield curve inversion has stopped is largely unimportant. See this weeks article on this very topic in the Economist. URL: https://www.economist.com/united-states/2019/11/14/americas-yield-curve-is-no-longer-inverted
It is 3.7 percent right now and the economy is slowing.

The last time the U3 reached 4% was January 2019, and in the past 24 months it has reached or exceeded 4% seven times (including Jan 2019) [1] - which is ~29% of the time. However, last month it was just 3.6% and there are signs that the U.S. economy is holding up well despite a global slowdown [2] - so, unless economic conditions change, as of now I find it unlikely that the 4% mark will be reached despite a base rate that indicates this is likely. I mostly hold this view because the unemployment data shows that, barring a recession, the U3 rarely rises steeply - and a recession seems unlikely at the moment. I will revise if the unemployment rate ticks up from 3.6% in the next few months.  [1] https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000
[2] https://www.wsj.com/articles/jerome-powell-to-testify-before-house-budget-committee-on-economic-outlook-11573736401
Recessions don't happen in election years.
